meta.title: SQL Injection Prevention - Prisma-SQL Security
meta.description: SQL injection prevention methodology using parameter binding, schema-based validation, and 137 security-focused tests (current suite)
meta.keywords: sql injection prevention, parameterized queries, sql security, database security, prisma security

hero.title: SQL Injection
hero.subtitle: User-provided values are never interpolated into SQL text ‚Äî values are bound via parameter placeholders (dialect-specific, e.g. $1 or ?)

stats.label: Value interpolation
stats.description: User data never appears in SQL text

threat.title: Understanding SQL injection
threat.subtitle: SQL injection remains one of the most critical web application vulnerabilities
threat.description: SQL injection occurs when untrusted data is incorporated into SQL text without safe parameter binding. Attackers can manipulate query meaning to access unauthorized data, modify records, or trigger unintended operations.

items.name: Authentication bypass
items.description: Attempts to bypass login by making the WHERE condition always true

items.name: Data exfiltration
items.description: Uses UNION to attempt extracting data from other tables

items.name: Destructive commands
items.description: Attempts to append extra statements to delete data

items.name: Parameter order bug abuse
items.attack: Exploit: If placeholders and params are mismatched, authorization checks may use the wrong values
items.description: Example: WHERE userId=$1 AND isAdmin=$2, but params=[true, 123] instead of [123, true] can incorrectly grant admin access

protection.title: Multi-layer protection strategy
protection.subtitle: Every query passes through multiple security validation layers

layers.title: Layer 1: Automatic parameter binding
layers.description: All user-provided values are converted into bound parameters. Values do not enter SQL text as literals.
guarantees: User values are represented using dialect-specific placeholders (e.g. $1 or ?)
Array inputs are parameterized (expanded placeholders or array parameters depending on dialect/strategy)
NULL and optional values handled without concatenating user input into SQL text
Date/time values are parameterized
JSON values are parameterized

layers.title: Layer 2: Field name validation
layers.description: Every field name is validated against the Prisma schema metadata before query generation.
guarantees: Only schema-defined fields are allowed
Relation filters validated via schema metadata
No arbitrary field names accepted
Unsupported/computed fields rejected where applicable
Prototype pollution payloads are rejected (e.g. __proto__, constructor)

layers.title: Layer 3: Identifier sanitization
layers.description: Table names, column names, and aliases are validated and safely quoted/escaped as required.
guarantees: Control characters rejected
Reserved keywords are quoted when needed
Schema qualification supported where configured
Double-quote escaping (or dialect equivalent) for identifiers
Maximum identifier length enforced per dialect

layers.title: Layer 4: Operator validation
layers.description: Only known, safe operators are allowed for each field type.
guarantees: String operators: contains, startsWith, endsWith
Numeric operators: lt, lte, gt, gte
Array operators: in, notIn with type validation
Logical operators: AND, OR, NOT validated structurally
Unknown operators rejected immediately

layers.title: Layer 5: Parameter order guarantee
layers.description: Strict ordering ensures each placeholder maps to exactly one parameter in insertion order, preventing mismatches.
guarantees: Sequential counter prevents reordering
Lockstep SQL building and param array construction
No intermediate buffer or reordering operations
Test verification: generated SQL and params always align
One-to-one correspondence: placeholder N ‚Üí params[N-1] (or equivalent mapping for the dialect)

formalProofs.title: Formal security guarantees
formalProofs.subtitle: Proof sketches for injection resistance under stated design assumptions (parameter binding, no raw-SQL bypass, correct driver usage)

proofs.title: Theorem 1: Value isolation
proofs.statement: For all user-provided values V, there exists no execution path where V appears as SQL text in the generated query string.
proofs.proof:
By construction, all code paths that handle user values call addParameter(value) which:
1. Stores the value in a separate params array
2. Returns a placeholder token for the SQL text
3. Only the placeholder token is appended into the SQL string
4. The database driver receives SQL text and parameter values separately
‚à¥ User values are not parsed as SQL syntax

proofs.title: Theorem 2: Field name closure
proofs.statement: The set of field names F in any generated query is a subset of schema-defined fields S, i.e., F ‚äÜ S.
proofs.proof:
For every field reference:
1. Field name extracted from query object
2. Lookup performed against schema metadata
3. If the field does not exist in the schema, an error is thrown
4. Only validated fields reach SQL generation
‚à¥ Arbitrary field names cannot appear in SQL

proofs.title: Theorem 3: Operator safety
proofs.statement: For any operator O applied to field F, O is a member of the allowed operators for F's type T.
proofs.proof:
Operator validation algorithm:
1. Extract field type T from schema
2. Define allowed_ops(T) = { valid operators for type T }
3. For operator O in query:
   - If O ‚àâ allowed_ops(T), throw error
   - Else apply operator using parameter binding
‚à¥ Only type-appropriate operators can be used

proofs.title: Theorem 4: Identifier safety
proofs.statement: All SQL identifiers I are validated to prevent control characters and to ensure safe quoting/escaping per dialect.
proofs.proof:
Identifier processing:
1. Reject if contains control characters
2. Escape internal quote characters per dialect rules
3. Quote identifiers when required (reserved keywords or special characters)
4. Enforce per-dialect identifier length limits
‚à¥ Identifiers cannot break SQL syntax or introduce injected tokens

proofs.title: Theorem 5: Parameter order consistency
proofs.statement: For every placeholder position N emitted into the SQL text, params[N-1] contains the exact value intended for that position, with no reordering or mismatch.
proofs.proof:
Parameter ordering guarantee:
1. A single tracker maintains insertion order
2. Each add() call appends the value to params and immediately emits the next placeholder token
3. SQL text construction and params construction proceed in lockstep
4. No intermediate reordering operations occur
‚à¥ One-to-one correspondence is maintained throughout

testCoverage.title: Comprehensive security test coverage
testCoverage.subtitle: 137 tests validate protection against common SQL injection vectors and edge cases (current suite)

categories.title: Value parameterization (basic.test.ts)
tests: SQL keywords as values: DROP TABLE users
Union attacks: ' UNION SELECT * FROM users--

categories.title: Field name validation (identifiers.test.ts)
tests: Reject malicious field names in SELECT
Reject malicious field names in WHERE
Reject malicious field names in ORDER BY
Reject SQL injection in field names

categories.title: Array operator safety (array-operators.test.ts)
tests: IN with malicious arrays: ['; DROP--', 'UNION SELECT--']
NOT IN with injection: ['; TRUNCATE--', 'DELETE FROM--']

categories.title: Edge cases (edge-cases.test.ts)
tests: Stacked queries: '; DROP TABLE users; SELECT
UNION-based: UNION ALL SELECT null, password

categories.title: Parameter order verification (basic.test.ts)
tests: Complex queries maintain order across conditions
Nested OR/AND conditions preserve parameter sequence
Relation filters maintain correct parameter mapping

unsafe.title: ‚ùå Unsafe: string concatenation
unsafe.code:
const email = req.body.email
const sql = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE email = '" + email + "'"

safe.title: ‚úÖ Safe: automatic parameter binding

sections.title: Parameter management
sections.description: Centralized parameter tracking ensures every user-provided value is parameter bound and order-stable

sections.title: Field validation
sections.description: Schema-based validation prevents arbitrary field access

sections.title: Identifier quoting
sections.description: Dialect-aware identifier validation and quoting prevents identifier-based syntax injection

practices.title: Never disable validation
practices.description: Do not bypass schema validation or field checking. These are critical security layers.
practices.do: Use the library as designed with full validation
practices.dont: Bypass schema validation or inject raw SQL into query text

practices.title: Keep schema updated
practices.description: Ensure your Prisma schema accurately reflects your database structure.
practices.do: Run prisma db pull and prisma generate after schema changes
practices.dont: Use outdated DMMF or schema definitions

practices.title: Validate input types
practices.description: TypeScript provides compile-time safety, but runtime validation adds defense in depth.
practices.do: Use Prisma's generated types for query arguments
practices.dont: Cast user input to any before passing to queries

practices.title: Monitor query patterns
practices.description: Log and monitor generated SQL and parameters in production to detect anomalies and misuse.
practices.do: Enable query logging and review patterns

securityCallout.title: How do we prevent SQL injection?
securityCallout.description: Multi-layer validation with parameter binding, schema-based field checks, and 137 security tests (current suite)

cta.title: Security through design
cta.subtitle: SQL injection protection is built into every layer of this library. Review the security tests and implementation details directly.
